10.1016/j.mcat.2024.114049 Scheme 1 Possible pathways for the reductive amination of 6-HHN to HMDA. Scheme 1 Fig. 1 Influence of reaction temperature on the reductive amination of 6-HHN. Reaction conditions: 0.5 g 6-HHN, 5 mL NH3·H2O, 100 mg catalyst, 6 MPa H2, 14 h. Fig 1 Fig. 2 Influence of H2 pressure on the reductive amination of 6-HHN. Reaction conditions: 0.5 g 6-HHN, 5 mL NH3·H2O, 100 mg catalyst, 190 °C, 14 h. Fig 2 Fig. 3 Influence of NH3 to 6-HHN molar ratio on the reductive amination of 6-HHN. Reaction conditions: 0.5 g 6-HHN, 100 mg catalyst, 190 °C, 6 MPa H2, 14 h. Fig 3 Fig. 4 Influence of amount of catalyst on the reductive amination of 6-HHN. Reaction conditions: 0.5 g 6-HHN, 5 mL NH3·H2O, 190 °C, 6 MPa H2, 14 h. School of Chemical Engineering and Technology Hebei University of Technology Tianjin 300131 China Hexamethylenediamine (HMDA), which is a crucial intermediate for the production of polyamides and other chemical products, was synthesized from the reductive amination of 6-hydroxycapronitrile (6-HHN) derived from ε‑caprolactone (ε‑CPL) with aqueous ammonia as the ammonia source. A bimetallic catalyst Co10Ru1/MgO-γ-Al2O3(0.3:1)-500 was found to be effective in the reaction. Over this catalyst the conversion of 6-HHN reached up to 100 %, with a HMDA selectivity of 38.14 %, corresponding to a yield of 38.14 %, and the total selectivity of HMDA, 6-amino-1-hexanol (AHO) and hexamethyleneimine (HMI) of 86.92 %. Characterization results disclosed that Co and Ru uniformly disperse on the surface of the MgO-Al2O3 mixed-oxide support, and respectively acts as the dehydrogenation-hydrogenation active species in the reaction with seldom agglomeration either in catalytic run or regeneration process. It was also found that some nonvolatile carbonaceous substances deposited on the surfaces of the catalyst during a catalytic run, leading to the deactivation of the catalyst. The catalysis of the catalyst could be largely recovered by high temperature calcination to remove the carbon deposits, followed by reduction with H2. Introduction Hexamethylenediamine (HMDA) is mainly used to react with adipic acid to produce nylon-66 and sebacic acid to produce nylon-610 [1]. Nylon-66 is a thermoplastic resin that can be used to prepare engineering plastics, food packaging films, and synthetic fibers. Nylon-610 has high strength and excellent impact toughness, excellent wear resistance, oil resistance and self-lubrication, and is widely used in the manufacture of gears, bearings, gaskets and oil storage vessels [2,3]. HMDA reacts with phosgene to produce hexamethylene diisocyanate (HDI) [4]. HDI is a commonly used monomer in the preparation of aliphatic diisocyanates (ADI), from which approximately 60 % of ADI are prepared. HDI and HDI derivative products are widely used in aviation, automotive, construction, coatings and other fields [5]. Currently, HMDA is predominantly manufactured by the hydrogenation of adiponitrile (ADN) over various catalysts [6–8]. Now, ADN is mainly manufactured by the following two processes in industry, which are the coupling of acrylonitrile via electroreduction [9–11], and the direct hydrocyanidation of 1,3-butadiene developed by DuPont [12–14]. In principle, both the processes have the virtues of excellent atomic economy and cheap raw materials. However, the former shows the defect of low selectivity in practice, and the latter suffers from the essential disadvantage of massive use of highly toxic hydrocyanic acid. Additionally, both acrylonitrile and 1,3-butadiene used in the two processes are belong to petroleum-based raw materials, which are not sustainable in oil-poor countries such as China. Therefore, it is necessary to explore processes for producing HMDA instead of the hydrogenation of ADN, and indeed some novel protocols such as caprolactam (CPL) amination [15], adipaldehyde reductive amination [16], 1,6-hexanediol (HDO) reductive amination [17] have been developed. The ammonification method of CPL involves the ring opening reaction of CPL with ammonia under the action of a phosphate catalyst to produce 6-aminohexanamide, which further undergoes dehydration reaction to produce 6-aminohexanitrile. Finally, the 6-aminohexanitrile undergoes a deep hydrogenation reaction with H2 to produce HMDA, 6-aminohexanitrile can achieve a higher yield of HMDA under mild reaction conditions, and the most difficult step in the CPL amination process is the first step of amination dehydration. The dehydration reaction is reversible, requiring timely discharge of water generated during the reaction process and the introduction of excess ammonia gas to continuously generate 6-aminohexanitrile. Therefore, the promotion of the process of producing HMDA through CPL amination is slow [15]. Adipaldehyde ammonification method is a hydrogenation reaction of adipaldehyde in the presence of ammonia and H2 to generate HMDA [16]. This reaction often uses transition metal catalysts, which can adjust the acidity and alkalinity of the catalyst, reduce the adsorption of amines in the reaction, reduce the generation of by-products, and exhibit good activity and selectivity. HDO ammonification method is a dehydration reaction between HDO and ammonia under high temperature and pressure, directly generating the target product HMDA. Li [17] has developed an environmentally friendly route for producing HMDA through catalytic reduction ammonification of HDO in the presence of H2. They added HDO, catalyst, and tert butanol to a stainless steel high-pressure reactor, HDO underwent ammonia dehydration reaction under the action of the catalyst to generate HMDA. Due to the high temperature and pressure required for HDO ammonification, low raw material conversion rate, and many by-products during the reaction process, it is currently not suitable for large-scale industrial production. In recent years, heterogeneous or homogeneous catalytic systems have made great progress in reducing amination of alcohols, which consists of three main steps: dehydrogenation and oxidation of alcohol hydroxyl groups to carbonyl groups, carbonyl imidization, and imine hydrogenation. Heterogeneous catalysts have been widely used in reducing amination of alcohols due to their mild reaction conditions, high selectivity of primary amine and recyclability, the metal active components are noble metals, such as Ru, Rh, and Pd, and non-noble metals, such as Co, Ni, Cu, and Fe [18–21]. Lei [22] prepared a Co catalyst supported on γ-Al2O3 for the liquid-phase ammonolysis of ethylene glycol to produce high-value-added ethanolamine. Co nanoparticles above 4 nm showed the highest ethanolamine selectivity (73.6 %). Smaller Co nanoparticles (above 2 nm) were exhibited a higher selectivity for glycolaldehyde due to an insufficient ability to catalyze the condensation reaction between glycolaldehyde and NH3. Therefore, the reductive amination of alcohols is becoming the most promising and effective method because of its abundant source materials, low cost, and simple process. Recently, we successfully developed a novel process for the synthesis of ADN from the catalytic amination of 6‑hydroxyhexanenitrile (6-HHN) from ε‑caprolactone (ε‑CPL) [23], which is produced from the Baeyer-Villiger oxidation of cyclohexanone [24]. Furthermore, cyclohexanone can be produced from the coal-based benzene via the route of selective hydrogenation of benzene to cyclohexene [25], hydration of cyclohexene to cyclohexanol [26], and dehydrogenation of cyclohexanol to cyclohexanone [27]. In view of the structure of 6-HHN, both the hydroxy and cyano groups can be transformed into amino group by reductive amination and hydrogenation respectively [6–8,17]. We are interested in developing a novel process for the production of HMDA from 6-HHN instead of the hydrogenation of ADN. To this end, a MgO-γ-Al2O3 composite supported Co-Ru bimetallic catalyst Co10Ru1/MgO-γ-Al2O3(0.3:1)−500 was found to be good in the catalytic amination of 6-HHN to HMDA through the screening of the active ingredients, support compositions, preparation conditions of the catalysts, as well as the reaction parameters. Meanwhile, the morphologies of Co and Ru in the catalyst, as well as the relationship between catalyst structure and catalytic performance were elucidated by catalyst characterization in combination with catalytic results. Experimental section Materials All reactants were analytical grade and utilized as received without further purification. γ-Al2O3 and MgO were acquired from Aladdin; Co(NO3)2·6H2O, Ni(NO3)2·6H2O, and ZnO were obtained from Macklin; RuCl3·xH2O was sourced from Innochem; NH3·H2O (25∼28 %), NaOH, and Na2CO3 were obtained from Tianjin Fuchen Chemical Reagent Company; N-Methylpyrrolidone, HMDA, AHO, HMI standards for GC calibration were all procured from Heowns. 6-HHN with a purity of 99 % was prepared by ourselves as the patented process. Catalytically reductive amination of ε-caprolactone to 6-HHN According to the preparation method of 6-HHN in the literature [28]. Sesbania powder, as the adhesive, is fully mixed with ZnO and proper amount of water to form a gel, and the gel is fully ground in a mortar to form a solid. Grind the solid into catalyst precursor by kneading and extrusion method, and dry it in an 80 °C oven. Place the dried solid in a muffle furnace and heat it up to 500 °C for calcination to obtain the required catalyst. 6-HHN was synthesized from ε-caprolactone under optimal reaction conditions (atmospheric pressure, reaction temperature 295 °C, molar ratio of ε-caprolactone to ammonia feed 1:18, and residence time 5 s) in a fixed bed reactor. The yield of 6-HHN was as high as 83.4 %. Then, the synthesized 6-HHN reaction solution was purified, and after separation and purification, the GC purity of 6-HHN reached 99 %. Catalyst preparation The catalysts designed in this work are denoted as CoxRuy/MgO-γ-Al2O3(m:n)-RT, x and y represent the mass fraction of the metal active components, m:n signifies the MgO to γ-Al2O3 mass ratio, and RT represents the reduction temperature. Unless otherwise specified, the catalysts used in the text were obtained at reduction temperature of 500 °C. As an example, Co10Ru1/MgO-γ-Al2O3(0.3:1)−500 was prepared with the following procedure. In 40 mL of distilled water were dissolved 0.4938 g of Co(NO3)2·6H2O and 0.0205 g of RuCl3·xH2O. Subsequently, 0.2054 g of MgO and 0.6846 g of γ-Al2O3 were introduced into the aqueous solution under stirring at 60 °C. Another aqueous solution prepared by dissolving 5.09 g of Na2CO3 and 3.84 g of NaOH in 50 mL of deionized water was added dropwise into the above suspension under stirring at 60 °C until the pH reached approximately 10.0, and then the resulting reaction mixture was aged at 70 °C for 2 h. The mixture was cooled to room temperature, and then centrifuged to collect the solid generated. The collected solid was washed several times with deionized water until the pH of the supernatant reached 7.0. The solid was dried in an oven at 100 °C for 12 h, and then was ground thoroughly to give a solid powder. The solid powder was loaded into a muffle furnace and heated to 500 °C with a ramp rate of 5 °C/min, and calcined at this temperature for 3 h under air. The calcined solid powder was ground again and transferred into a tubular furnace. The tube furnace was heated to 500 °C with a ramp rate of 5 °C/min under a N2 atmosphere, and then the solid powder was reduced with H2 for 3 h to afford the catalyst Co10Ru1/MgO-γ-Al2O3(0.3:1)−500. Catalytic test The reductive amination of 6-HHN to HMDA was conducted in a 50 mL high-pressure autoclave. Initially, 6-HHN (0.5 g), catalyst (100 mg), and aqueous ammonia (5 mL) were introduced into the autoclave. The sealed autoclave was purged with H2 for five times to replace the residual air, and charged with H2 to 6 MPa at room temperature. The autoclave was subsequently heated to the desired temperature, and then the reaction was run at this temperature for a specific period of time. After reaction, the catalyst was filtered out, and the liquid phase was subjected to quantitative analysis by gas chromatography (GC), utilizing n-methylpyrrolidone as an internal standard. The conversion of 6-HHN (C), the selectivity (S), the yield (Y) and the turnover frequency (TOF) of the target product were calculated as follows: (1) C ( % ) = moles of 6 − HHN reacted moles of 6 − HHN fed × 100 % (2) S ( % ) = moles of HMDA generated moles of 6 − HHN reacted × 100 % (3) Y ( % ) = C × S × 100 % (4) TOF( h − 1 ) = moles of HMDA generated moles of catalyst × reaction time Catalyst characterization Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis was conducted on a Bruker D8 Advance X-ray diffractometer (Germany) equipped with a Cu Kα source (λ= 0.154 nm). The analysis covered a 2θ range of 10°∼90° at a scan speed of 6°/min. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed on a Thermo Scientific K-Alpha+ spectrometer with an Al Kα X-ray excitation source. The BET specific surface area, total pore volume, and pore size distribution were determined through a pulsed N2 adsorption-desorption method at 77 K using a Micromeritics ASAP 2460. The NH3 temperature programmed desorption analysis of the catalyst was performed using a Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920 chemical adsorption analyzer to explore the influence of the acidity on the catalytic performance of the catalyst in the reductive amination of 6-HHN.Transmission electron micrographs (TEM) and high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) images were taken on a JEOL JEM-2100F instrument operating at an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. For TEM analysis, the samples were ultrasonically dispersed in anhydrous ethanol and then suspended on an ultrathin Cu grid-supported carbon foil. Results and discussion Catalytically reductive amination of 6-HHN to HMDA Pathways for product generation In principles, the reductive amination of 6-HHN involves two steps: the hydrogenation of nitrile to amine via imine as an intermediate [29], and the reductive amination of alcohol to amine consisting of the dehydrogenation of alcohol to carbonyl compound, the condensation of carbonyl with ammonia to imine and the hydrogenation of imine to amine [30–33,18]. The experimental results revealed that the nitrile moiety of 6-HHN was readily hydrogenated to AHO over the catalyst Co10Ru1/MgO-γ-Al2O3(0.3:1). With the formation of AHO, HMDA, HMI and nonvolatile carbonaceous compounds were generated and detected in different selectivity. Based on the principles and experimental results, the reaction pathways for the reductive amination of 6-HHN are proposed and depicted in Scheme 1 . Initially, the 6-HHN is reduced readily to AHO via consecutive hydrogenation. Once the formation of AHO, it is dehydrogenated to 6-aminohexanal (6-AHA) which intermediately condenses with ammonia to form 6-iminohexylamine (6-IHA). 6-IHA as a key intermediate undergoes hydrogenation and cyclization via intramolecular nucleophilic addition to generate HMDA and azepan-2-amine (aze-PA), respectively. The aze-PA is converted to 1-azacycloheptene (aza-CHPE) by stripping of ammonia, and then aza-CHPE undergoes hydrogenation to HMI. HMI can be also generated via the intramolecular nucleophilic addition of 6-AHA to generate azepan-2-ol (aze-PO), followed by the dehydration of aze-PO to aza-CHPE which undergoes further hydrogenation to generate HMI [34,35]. Besides, HMDA may also be converted to HMI under strong conditions or excessively long reaction time [17,36,37]. For example, Yin [36] present a cobalt-catalyzed selective alkylation of amines with amines to synthesize a large variety of secondary amines, and investigated the possibility of intramolecular alkylation of amines. Yin used HMDA as the substrate and reacted at 120 °C for 24 h, resulting in a yield of 91 % for the product HMI. Khusnutdinova [37] uses water as the only reagent, with no added bases, oxidants, or reductants, thus establishing a green method of direct deamination of aliphatic amines in water. This deamination reaction can be used for facile and selective, entropy-driven cyclization of diamines to HMI at 100 °C in water with 70 % yield. HMDA dimerization or condensation with 6-IHA, 6-AHA can afford HMDA dimer bis(hexamethylene)triamine. Bis(hexamethylene)triamine condenses further with 6-IHA, 6-AHA and HMDA to form carbonaceous deposits on the surface of the catalyst. It should be noted that all the hydrogenation and dehydrogenation reactions take place over the Co and Ru active sites of the catalyst and the condensation reactions mainly take place on the acidic sites of the support MgO-γ-Al2O3. Screening of catalyst compositions In principle, the catalytically reductive amination of 6-HHN to HMDA involves the hydrogenation of nitrile to amine and the reductive amination of alcohol to amine. It was found that heterogeneous catalysts with Ni, Co, Cu, Fe, Ru, Pd, and Pt as active species showed good performances in the above two elementary reactions [38–41]. Therefore, some γ-Al2O3 supported monometallic catalysts with metal content of 10 % were prepared and evaluated in the reductive amination of 6-HHN to HMDA. As depicted in Table 1 (entries 1–7), the conversion of 6-HHN reached 100 % over the catalysts except for the two ones with Cu and Fe as active species. However, only Co10/γ-Al2O3 and Ru10/γ-Al2O3 gave HMDA in the low selectivity of 7.57 % and 15.36 %, respectively. The main product was determined to be AHO, which indicated that the reductive amination of alcohol was more difficult than the hydrogenation of nitrile under the same reaction conditions. Besides, a considerable amount of HMI was also generated from the cyclization of reaction intermediates (Scheme 1). Generally, bimetallic catalysts exhibited good catalysis compared to monometallic catalysts in the hydrogenation of nitriles to amines and the reductive amination of alcohols due to the synergy effect between the two metals [42–44]. Thus, a bimetallic catalyst Co10Ru1/γ-Al2O3 was prepared to improve the selectivity of HMDA. As expected, the selectivity of HMDA was increased to 30.41 % with a sharp decrease in the selectivity of AHO compared to those over the two monometallic catalysts (Table 1, entry 8). Meanwhile, the selectivity of HMI was increased too, indicating the enhancement of the catalyst's dehydrogenation activity, thus leading to more alcohol moiety dehydrogenation to aldehyde intermediates (Scheme 1). It was reported that MgO-Al2O3 mixed-oxide supported bimetallic catalysts showed good catalytic performances in the hydrogenation of nitriles because of tuned addition of MgO into Al2O3 leading to suitable surface acidity, large surface area, uniform and fine dispersion of metal particles of catalysts [45,46]. Thus, several Co10Ru1/MgO-γ-Al2O3 bimetallic catalysts with different MgO to γ-Al2O3 mass ratios were prepared and evaluated in the reductive amination of 6-HHN. As expected, the selectivity of HMDA increased with the doping of MgO to γ-Al2O3 and reached its maximum of 36.06 % at a MgO to γ-Al2O3 mass ratio of 0.3:1, meanwhile, the total selectivity of HMDA, AHO and HMI also reached its maximum of 84.73 % (Table 1, entries 9–11). The increased activity of the catalyst could be attributed to the increased alkaline sites on the catalyst surface by MgO introduction, facilitating ammonia desorption and promoting the breakage of OH bonds of hydroxy groups to increase the concentration of alkoxy intermediates on the catalyst surface, thus leading to enhanced catalytic activity [1]. With a further increase in MgO to γ-Al2O3 mass ratio, the selectivity of HMDA and the total selectivity of HMDA, AHO and HMI both decreased (Table 1, entries 11–13). However, the selectivity of both AHO and HMI changed randomly with an increase in MgO doped. The results could be ascribed to that excessive MgO loading led to a drastic decrease in acidic sites, being unfavorable for the dehydrogenation of hydroxyl and the subsequent carbonyl reductive amination [47]. After the determination of the mixed-oxide composition, the contents of cobalt and ruthenium were screened systematically. First, several bimetallic catalysts were prepared with varying cobalt to ruthenium mass ratio while maintaining a fixed Ru loading of 1 wt% and a MgO to γ-Al2O3 mass ratio of 0.3:1. The catalytic results showed that either increase or decrease in cobalt content from 10 % led to the decrease in the selectivity of HMDA (Table 1, entries 11, 14–17). Meanwhile, with the decrease in cobalt content from 10 % the selectivity of AHO increased sharply, and the selectivity of HMI decreased gradually. With the increase in cobalt content from 10 % the selectivity of AHO decreased slowly and the selectivity of HMI changed slightly. The results indicated that a lower cobalt to ruthenium mass ratio in the bimetallic catalyst is in favor of the hydrogenation of nitrile, but detrimental to the dehydrogenation of alcohol to aldehyde. Next, a series of bimetallic catalysts were also prepared with varying cobalt to ruthenium mass ratio while maintaining a fixed cobalt loading of 10 wt% and a MgO to γ-Al2O3 mass ratio of 0.3:1. The catalysts were also evaluated in the target reaction. As shown in Table 1 (entries 11, 18–23), the selectivity of HMDA increased with the increase in ruthenium content from 0 to 1 % and reached its maximum of 36.06 %, then decreased with a further increase in ruthenium content from 1 % to 3 %. The selectivity of HMI showed a similar change trend as that of HMDA. In contrast, the selectivity of AHO decreased continuously from 76.21 % to 23.35 % with the increase in ruthenium content from 0 to 3 %, which seems to be contradictory to the previous conclusions that a lower cobalt to ruthenium mass ratio is in favor of the hydrogenation of nitrile. In fact, the two seemingly contradictory results exactly reveal that a suitable cobalt to ruthenium mass ratio, being 10:1, is essential to ensure the catalyst with good catalytic performance. Consequently, the optimal catalyst compositions are the cobalt to ruthenium mass ratio to be 10:1, MgO to γ-Al2O3 mass ratio of 0.3:1. Screening of reduction temperature in catalyst preparation After the determination of the catalyst compositions, the reduction temperature during preparing the catalysts was investigated because it can impact both the size of metal particles and the presence of active species on the catalyst surface, thus influencing the catalytic performance of the catalyst. Table 2 shows the results of the reductive amination of 6-HHN over the catalysts obtained at different reduction temperature. As can be seen, the conversion of 6-HHN was 100 % over all the catalysts. However, the selectivity of HMDA increased with the increase in reduction temperature from 450 °C to 500 °C, and reached its maximum of 36.06 %, the catalyst exhibits a significantly higher turnover frequency (TOF) value of 0.084 h −1. Then the selectivity of HMDA began to decrease with a further increase in reduction temperature and decreased to 20.52 % at reduction temperature of 700 °C. The selectivity of HMI changed similarly to that of HMDA, but reached its maximum of 26.61 % at the reduction temperature of 600 °C. On the other hand, the selectivity of AHO decreased continuously from 28.04 % to 5.48 % with the increase in reduction temperature from 450 °C to 700 °C. When the reduction temperature is 450 °C, insufficient reduction leads to a low number of active species on the catalyst surface, resulting in poor catalytic activity and lower HMDA selectivity. When the reduction temperature exceeds 500 °C, the metal active components will accumulate on the surface, the particle size will increase, leading to a decrease in the specific surface area of the catalyst, affecting catalytic activity and further reducing HMDA selectivity [48]. In summary, the most suitable reduction temperature for the catalyst is 500 °C. Optimization of reaction conditions With the catalyst Co10Ru1/MgO-γ-Al2O3(0.3:1)−500 in hand, the reaction conditions were then optimized in order to get a high yield of HMDA. First, the influence of the reaction temperature on the reaction was investigated in the range of 160∼200 °C while maintaining 6 MPa H2, 0.5 g 6-HHN, 5 mL NH3·H2O, 100 mg catalyst, and reaction time 14 h. As shown in Fig. 1 and Table S1, the conversion of 6-HHN remained at 100 % with the change in temperature. However, the selectivity of HMDA initially increased from 15.64 % to 36.06 % with the increase in temperature from 160 °C to 190 °C and then declined to 28.02 % with a further increase in temperature to 200 °C. The selectivity of HMI increased continuously from 9.43 % to 27.92 % with the increase in temperature from 160 °C to 200 °C, but the selectivity of AHO decreased constantly from 58.32 % to 15.95 %. Besides, the maximum total selectivity of HMDA, HMI and AHO was also received at 190 °C. The results indicated that high temperature could enhance the dehydrogenation of AHO to 6-AHA, which underwent condensation with ammonia to form 6-IHA (Scheme 1). Once the formation of IHA, it could be transformed to HMDA and HMI through hydrogenation and intramolecular cyclization, respectively, leading to increase of the selectivity of both HMDA and HMI. However, an excessive high temperature such as 200 °C gave rise to oligomerization of IHA to generate nonvolatile carbonaceous substances deposited on the surface of catalyst as disclosed by XRD, XPS and TEM analysis, thus leading to the lower selectivity of HMDA and HMI. The HRMS analysis of the reaction mixture showed that the by-products were mainly dimers and trimers produced through dimerization, cyclization, and oligomerization, with bis(hexamethylene)triamine and 6-(azepan-1-yl)hexan-1-amine as the dimers [17,49] and N,N'-bis(6-aminohexyl)−1,6-hexanediamine as the trimers [50,51]. Hydrogen pressure is an important fact in the reductive amination of 6-HHN to HMDA. Therefore, the impact of hydrogen pressure on the reaction was investigated, and the results are shown in Fig. 2 and Table S2. When hydrogen is not added to the reaction, the conversion rate of 6-HHN is low, and the selectivity of HMDA is 4.75 %. This is because a large amount of ammonia in the system forms metal nitrides with the metal active components of the catalyst, leading to catalyst deactivation [52], and the cyanide group in 6-HHN is also difficult to hydrogenate to form amino groups. After adding hydrogen, the conversion rate of 6-HHN is 100 %. The selectivity of both HMDA and HMI initially increased with the increase in hydrogen pressure from 3 MPa to 6 MPa, and respectively reached their maximus of 36.06 % and 24.33 % at 6 MPa, then decreased to 27.06 % and 18.39 % with a further increase in hydrogen pressure to 7 MPa. On the contrary, the selectivity of AHO decreased to its minimum of 24.36 % at the hydrogen pressure of 6 MPa, and rebounded to 41.95 % at the hydrogen pressure of 7 MPa. The results indicated that a higher pressure of hydrogen could accelerate the hydrogenation of nitrile moiety of 6-HHN to AHO, which enhance the formation of 6-AHA and subsequent the transformation of 6-AHA to IHA, thus leading to more formation of HMDA and HMI (Scheme 1). However, an excessively high pressure of hydrogen such as 7 MPa inhibited the dehydrogenation of AHO to 6-AHA, thus leading to a high selectivity of AHO and low selectivity of both HMDA and HMI. Next, the influence of ammonia to 6-HHN molar ratio on the reductive amination of 6-HHN was explored. As shown in Fig. 3 and Table S3, the conversion of 6-HHN was always 100 % in all cases. When ammonia is not added, no HMDA is generated, and only a small amount of 6-HHN is generated into HMI through hydrogenation, cyclization and dehydration (Scheme 1). The selectivity of both HMDA and HMI initially increased with the increase in the ammonia to 6-HHN molar ratio from 0:1 to 16:1, and respectively reached their maximus of 36.06 % and 24.33 % at 16:1, then decreased to 29.73 % and 21.25 % with a further increase in the ammonia to 6-HHN molar ratio to 20:1. On the other hand, the selectivity of AHO decreased continuously with the increase in the ammonia to 6-HHN molar ratio. From a kinetic perspective, as ammonia is the main raw material for the reaction, increasing the amount of ammonia should make the reaction proceed in a positive direction. However, excessive amount of ammonia is not conducive to the progress of 6-HHN ammonification reaction. This is because as the amount of ammonia increases, ammonia becomes the dominant factor in the reaction, promoting the adsorption of ammonia on the catalyst surface, which is conducive to the progress of the reaction; When the amount of ammonia is too large, excessive water will affect the intermediate step of hydroxyl dehydrogenation to form imine in the 6-HHN ammonification reaction (Scheme 1). At the same time, excessive ammonia will occupy more active sites through chemical adsorption, forming competitive adsorption between ammonia and hydrogen, 6-HHN, which has adverse effects on the reaction. In the study of the synthesis of ethylenediamine through the amination of ethylene glycol, An [53] also found that an excessive amount of ammonia water is not conducive to the conversion of ethylenediamine. In summary, the optimal molar ratio of ammonia to 6-HHN is 16:1. Then, the optimal catalyst dosage in the reaction was screened in the range of 0 % to 25 % of substrate weight. As shown in Fig. 4 and Table S4, when no catalyst is added, the conversion rate of 6-HHN is only 26 %, and no HMDA is generated. After adding a certain amount of catalyst, the selectivity of HMDA initially increased with the increase in catalyst dosage and reached its maximum of 36.06 % at catalyst dosage of 20 wt%, and then declined with a further increase in catalyst dosage. The selectivity of AHO showed an opposite trend, and reached its minimum of 24.36 % at catalyst dosage of 20 wt%. Meanwhile, the selectivity of HMI increased continuously with the increase in catalyst dosage from 10 wt% to 25 wt%. Besides, the maximum total selectivity of HMDA, AHO and HMI was obtained at catalyst dosage of 15 wt%. It is obviously that a higher dosage of catalyst means more active sites in the reaction, therefore, the reaction can be finished in a shorter time when the catalyst dosage is 25 wt%, and the selectivity of HMDA, AHO, and HMI is 29.69 %, 25.93 %, and 25.51 %, respectively. In the process, some HMDA could be converted to nonvolatile carbonaceous substances deposited on the surface of the catalyst (Scheme 1). In view of the selectivity of HMDA the optimal catalyst dosage was chosen as 20 wt%. Finally, the effect of reaction time on the reaction was studied, and the results are shown in Fig. 5 and Table S5. As can be seen, the selectivity of HMDA increased initially with the extension of time and reached its maximum of 38.14 %, and then decreased with a further extension of time. The selectivity of HMI increased with the extension of time, accompanying with the decrease of the selectivity of AHO. The results can be attributed to that enough long time was necessary to complete the transformation of AHO to HMDA and HMI. However, excessive reaction time would lead to the conversion of HMDA to nonvolatile carbonaceous substances. Therefore, the optimal reaction time was determined to be 16 h. Based on the above experimental results, the optimal reaction conditions for the reductive amination of 6-HHN to HMDA over the catalyst Co10Ru1/MgO-γ-Al2O3(0.3:1)−500 were optimized to be a reaction temperature of 190 °C, hydrogen pressure of 6 MPa, catalyst dosage of 20% substrate weight, NH3 to 6-HHN molar ratio of 16:1, and a reaction time of 16 h. Under the optimal conditions, the conversion of 6-HHN was 100 %, with a HMDA selectivity of 38.14 %, corresponding to a yield of 38.14 %, and the total selectivity of HMDA, AHO and HMI of 86.92 %. Regeneration of catalyst After the first catalytic run, the catalyst Co10Ru1/MgO-γ-Al2O3(0.3:1)−500 was subjected directly to the next run under optimal reaction conditions. As shown in Fig. 6 and Table S6, the conversion of 6-HHN remained at 100 %. However, the selectivity of both HMDA and HMI decreased significantly to 15.25 % and 10.72 % from 38.14 % and 25.17 %, respectively. Meanwhile, the selectivity of AHO increased sharply from 23.61 % to 64.55 %. The catalytic deterioration of the catalyst was ascribed to the adsorption or deposition of nonvolatile carbonaceous substances on the catalyst surfaces leading to large decrease in surface area as disclosed by TEM (Fig. 11c) and N2 adsorption-desorption analysis (Table 3 ), which blocked the contact between reactants and active centers of the catalyst. Besides, the deterioration of the catalyst might be due to in part the partial transformation of γ-Al2O3 to boehmite structure as exhibited in Fig. 7c . The deactivated catalyst was then regenerated by calcination at 500 ℃ under air for 3 h, followed by reduction at 500 ℃ under H2 atmosphere for 3 h, from which the deposited nonvolatile carbonaceous substances were removed and the γ-Al2O3 was restored. The regenerated catalyst was subjected to the next run under optimal conditions. As shown in Fig. 6 and Table S6, the selectivity of both HMDA and HMI increased to 30.5 % and 25.42 %, respectively, with the decrease of the selectivity of AHO to 29.29 %. Continuing to use the catalyst twice, the selectivity of HMDA and HMI rapidly decreased, with the highest selectivity of AHO reaching 90.26 %. This is because the active sites of the catalyst were reduced, resulting in a large amount of AHO generated by the hydrogenation of 6-HHN being unable to be further converted into the target product (Scheme 1). The catalytic deterioration of the regenerated catalyst compared to the fresh one could be ascribed to the changes in texture of the catalyst after catalytic run and regeneration (Fig. 9 and Table 3). Catalyst characterization XRD analysis Fig. 7 shows the XRD patterns of the samples of fresh Co10/MgO-γ-Al2O3(0.3:1), as well as fresh, used and regenerated catalyst Co10Ru1/MgO-γ-Al2O3(0.3:1)−500. By comparing with the standard data of γ-Al2O3 (JCPDS 47–1770), MgO (JCPDS 45–0946), and Co0 (JCPDS 05–0727) and Ru0 (JCPDS 88–2333), no characteristic diffraction peaks of Ru0 are exhibited in the XRD patterns of the Co10Ru1/MgO-γ-Al2O3(0.3:1)−500 samples, which can be ascribed to the low content and good dispersion of ruthenium in the catalyst. The characteristic peaks of Co0 are observed but very weak, also indicating good dispersion of cobalt in the catalyst. Besides, the used sample of the catalyst Co10Ru1/MgO-γ-Al2O3(0.3:1)−500 exhibits a boehmite structure (JCPDS 21–1307), indicating partial transformation of γ-Al2O3 to impurity boehmite phase under the reaction conditions, which may lead to the deactivation of the catalyst in some degree. After regeneration by calcination followed by reduction, the γ-Al2O3 phase is completely restored, and the structure essentially reverts to its original state. There is no significant difference in the diffraction patterns between fresh and regenerated samples of the catalyst Co10Ru1/MgO-γ-Al2O3(0.3:1)−500. Therefore, the catalytic performance of the catalyst was largely recovered as shown in the section of catalytic test. XPS analysis To elucidate the chemical compositions and the states of Co and Ru on the catalyst surfaces, the above catalyst samples were further analyzed by XPS. Fig. S1 presents the wide scan XPS spectra of the catalyst samples. The XPS spectra revealed the presence of Co, Mg, Al, O, and C in the catalyst samples. The carbon in the fresh catalyst samples likely originates from CO2 adsorption in the air on the surfaces of the catalysts. However, almost no Ru was detected due to its low content in the surface of Co10Ru1/MgO-γ-Al2O3(0.3:1)−500. Table S7 displays the atomic percentage of each element in the catalyst samples. Notably, Mg and Al constitute the majority of metal elements on the catalyst surface, while the contents of catalytically active components Co and Ru is notably low-considerably less than their proportion in the catalyst preparation process, as indicated by the weak metal diffraction peak in the XRD figure discussed earlier. The excessively low contents of Co and Ru on the catalyst surfaces might be due to the migration of Co and Ru into the bulk phase of MgO-Al2O3 mixed-oxide during the preparation of the catalysts [54]. In addition, the C content on the surface of the used sample of Co10Ru1/MgO-γ-Al2O3(0.3:1)−500 is twice that of the fresh one, and the contents of Co and Ru are much small compared to those of the fresh one, which indicated the deposition of carbonaceous substances on the catalyst surfaces, being the main reason for the deactivation of the catalyst. After the regeneration of the catalyst by calcination followed by reduction with H2, the carbon deposits were eliminated and the contents of C, Co, and Ru were largely restored, and most of the catalytic performance of the catalyst was recovered. The fitted Co 2p XPS spectra for the catalysts are shown in Fig. 8 . For the XPS spectrum of the monometallic catalyst Co10/MgO-γ-Al2O3(0.3:1), the Co 2p3/2 binding energies of 777.82 eV and 780.52 eV are attributed to the Co0 and Co2+ species, respectively [55,56]. The Co2+ species detected in all of the catalyst samples is owing to the oxidation of Co0 species during XPS analysis, which is almost inevitable. In the XPS spectrum of the bimetallic catalyst Co10Ru1/MgO-γ-Al2O3(0.3:1)−500 (Fig. 8b), the Co 2p3/2 binding energies of Co0 and Co2+ species are found at 777.84 eV and 780.53 eV, respectively, which are almost identical to those of the monometallic catalyst. The results indicate that there is no interaction between Co and Ru species in the bimetallic catalyst. In other words, no Co-Ru alloy nanoparticles are present in the bimetallic catalyst. Therefore, the enhanced catalytic performance of the bimetallic catalyst Co10Ru1/MgO-γ-Al2O3(0.3:1)−500 compared to the monometallic catalyst Co10/MgO-γ-Al2O3(0.3:1) might originate from the simple additive effect of the catalysis of Co and Ru active species in the reductive amination of 6-HHN. The binding energies of Co 2p3/2 for Co0 species in the fresh (Fig. 8b), used (Fig. 8c), and regenerated (Fig. 8d) samples of Co10Ru1/MgO-γ-Al2O3(0.3:1)−500 are only slightly changed, indicating that the Co active species are basically stable during a catalytic run and the regeneration process of the catalyst. N2 adsorption-desorption analysis The textural properties of the catalyst Co10/MgO-γ-Al2O3(0.3:1) as well as the fresh, used and regenerated samples of Co10Ru1/MgO-γ-Al2O3(0.3:1)−500 were determined by N2 adsorption-desorption analysis. As shown in Fig. 9 , the catalyst Co10/MgO-γ-Al2O3(0.3:1) and the fresh and regenerated samples of Co10Ru1/MgO-γ-Al2O3(0.3:1)−500 all display a type of IV isotherms with a H1 hysteresis loop, and the presence of both micropores and mesopores with respective mean diameters of around 2 nm and 20 nm. The used sample of Co10Ru1/MgO-γ-Al2O3(0.3:1)−500 shows a type of V isotherms with a H3 hysteresis loop, suggesting irregular slit-shaped pores [57,58], and the only existence of micropores with a mean pore diameter around 2 nm. The textural properties of catalyst samples listed in Table 3 are consistent with the above description. The analysis results suggest again that some nonvolatile carbonaceous substances deposited on the surface of the catalyst during a catalytic run, and the deposits could be removed by calcination followed by H2 reduction, leading to basic recovery of its catalytic performance of the regenerated catalyst Co10Ru1/MgO-γ-Al2O3(0.3:1)−500. NH3 temperature programmed desorption analysis There are reports that appropriate alkaline sites can make it easier for alcohols to undergo chemical adsorption on the carrier, promoting the breaking of OH bonds. Acidic sites mainly promote the breaking of CH bonds, which is beneficial for the adsorption of reaction raw materials NH3 and imine intermediates. In addition, the alkaline sites greatly increase the concentration of alkoxy intermediates on the catalyst surface, causing carbonyl groups to undergo condensation reaction with NH3 under the catalysis of metal active components to form amino groups, thereby exhibiting a stronger promoting effect [59]. Fig. 10 shows the NH3-TPD curve of the catalyst after reduction at 500 °C. The catalyst has three ammonia desorption peaks in the range of 100–700 °C, corresponding to acid centers with different acid strengths. The weak acid adsorption (150–200 °C), medium strong acid adsorption (250–450 °C), and strong acid adsorption (550–750 °C) of ammonia on the surface of the support [60]. The ammonia desorption peak of catalyst (a) is high, while the ammonia desorption peak of catalyst (b) is relatively low. The addition of MgO changes the acid strength of the catalyst. This is because magnesium oxide itself is alkaline and has a low acidity, and weak adsorption strength can easily cause ammonia molecules adsorbed on the catalyst to desorb from the surface [61]. The desorption temperature of the strong acid sites in (b) shifts to the right, and the strength and number of acidic sites in the catalyst significantly decrease. That is to say, the addition of MgO changes the distribution of acidic sites on the catalyst, which may be due to the consumption of some strong acid sites by the addition of MgO, leading to the formation of new strong acid sites. Therefore, the synergistic effect of suitable acid-base sites promotes the improvement of reaction activity. TEM analysis Finally, the morphologies of the catalyst samples and the dispersions of the supported metal particles were detected by TEM, and the results are shown in Fig. 11 and Fig. S2. In the TEM image of Co10/MgO-γ-Al2O3(0.3:1) (Fig. 11a), the Co nanoparticles are well dispersed with an average diameter of 9.5 nm. In the TEM image of Co10Ru1/MgO-γ-Al2O3(0.3:1)−500 (Fig. 11b), the metal nanoparticles are also well dispersed with an average diameter of 9.3 nm, only slight decrease in metal dimeter with the doping of Ru. The TEM image of the used sample of Co10Ru1/MgO-γ-Al2O3(0.3:1)−500 (Fig. 11c) was blurred owing to the deposition of carbonaceous substances on the surface. The increase in the average diameter of the metal nanoparticles to 12.7 nm does not mean the agglomeration of the metal nanoparticles in catalytic run, but might be ascribed to the deposition of carbonaceous substances leading to invisibility of the metal nanoparticles with small sizes. The metal nanoparticles with an average of 9.7 nm are observed clearly again in the TEM image of the regenerated sample (Fig. 11d), suggesting that the carbon deposit was removed through regeneration and no serious agglomeration took place during catalytic run and regeneration process. The HRTEM images (Fig. S2) of the Co10Ru1/MgO-γ-Al2O3(0.3:1)−500 sample clearly manifested lattice fringes of 0.229 nm, which could be assigned to the 200 crystal plane of cubic structure of CoO [62], indicating that most of Co nanoparticles were oxidized to CoO during TEM analysis. The EDX element mapping (Fig. 12 ) shows clearly that Co and Ru species are uniformly but separately dispersed in the catalyst, directly confirming no formation of Co-Ru alloy during catalyst preparation. Conclusion A novel process for the synthesis of HMDA via the catalytic amination from 6‑HHN has been proposed. To this end, a bimetallic catalyst Co10Ru1/MgO-γ-Al2O3(0.3:1)−500 with good catalytic performance was obtained by screening of the active transition metals, supports, loading amounts of metals, mass ratio of Co to Ru, and reduction temperature in production of the catalyst. Then, the optimal parameters for the conversion of 6‑HHN to HMDA with aqueous ammonia as both ammonia source and solvent were obtained through the optimization of the catalyst dosage, H2 pressure, NH3 to 6-HHN molar ratio, reaction temperature, and reaction time. Under the optimal conditions, the conversion of 6-HHN reached 100 %, with a HMDA selectivity of 38.14 %, corresponding to a yield of 38.14 %, and the total selectivity of HMDA, AHO and HMI of 86.92 %. The XRD, XPS, and TEM analysis disclosed that Co and Ru uniformly disperse on the surface of the MgO-Al2O3 mixed-oxide support, and respectively acts as dehydrogenation-hydrogenation active species in the catalytic amination of 6-HHN to HMDA. The TEM and N2 adsorption-desorption analysis revealed that some nonvolatile carbonaceous substances deposited on the surfaces of the catalyst during a catalytic run, leading to the deactivation of the catalyst. The carbon deposits could be removed by calcination followed by reduction with H2 at 500 ℃, and seldom agglomeration took place of the metal nanoparticles either in catalytic run or during regeneration process. Therefore, the catalytic performance of the catalyst could be largely recovered after regeneration. coredata.dc:description: Hexamethylenediamine (HMDA), which is a crucial intermediate for the production of polyamides and other chemical products, was synthesized from the reductive amination of 6-hydroxycapronitrile (6-HHN) derived from ε‑caprolactone (ε‑CPL) with aqueous ammonia as the ammonia source. A bimetallic catalyst Co10Ru1/MgO-γ-Al2O3(0.3:1)-500 was found to be effective in the reaction. Over this catalyst the conversion of 6-HHN reached up to 100 %, with a HMDA selectivity of 38.14 %, corresponding to a yield of 38.14 %, and the total selectivity of HMDA, 6-amino-1-hexanol (AHO) and hexamethyleneimine (HMI) of 86.92 %. Characterization results disclosed that Co and Ru uniformly disperse on the surface of the MgO-Al2O3 mixed-oxide support, and respectively acts as the dehydrogenation-hydrogenation active species in the reaction with seldom agglomeration either in catalytic run or regeneration process. It was also found that some nonvolatile carbonaceous substances deposited on the surfaces of the catalyst during a catalytic run, leading to the deactivation of the catalyst. The catalysis of the catalyst could be largely recovered by high temperature calcination to remove the carbon deposits, followed by reduction with H2.
coredata.dc:title: Catalyst and process for the synthesis of hexamethylenediamine via catalytic amination from 6‑hydroxyhexanenitrile
